references: We compare FedDaDiL to other decentralized MSDA strategies over 5 visual DA benchmarks. We present an overview of our results in tableÂ 1. We use standard evaluation protocols in MSDA, namely, we perform adaptation with a ResNetÂ [37] backbone. The size of the backbone is selected to agree with previous researchÂ [6, 7, 8]. We run our experiments on a computer with a Ubuntu 22.04 OS, a 12th Gen Intel(R) CoreTM i9-12900H CPU with 64 GB of RAM, and with a NVIDIA RTX A100 GPU with 4GB of VRAM.

FedaDiL. For our method, we performed grid-search on the batch size nbsubscriptğ‘›ğ‘n_{b}, number of atoms Kğ¾K and number of samples nğ‘›n. For the number of atoms, we search over Kâˆˆ{2,â‹¯,6}ğ¾2â‹¯6K\in\{2,\cdots,6\}. We further parametrize nbsubscriptğ‘›ğ‘n_{b} and nğ‘›n by the number of classes ncsubscriptğ‘›ğ‘n_{c} (c.f., Table 1 in our main paper). We display the best parameters in table 2 below, alongside the cost of communication for this set of parameters. Note that, as we explore in our experiments, the performance of our method is robust with respect the choice of hyper-parameters.

references: Decentralized Visual Domain Adaptation. In the following we refer to tableÂ 2(e), where we summarize our comparisons. First, FedAVG is a strong baseline when there is a limited amount of data. Indeed, on small benchmarks such as ImageCLEF and Office31, it performs better or equally than existing decentralized MSDA algorithms. This is not true on larger benchmarks, such as Adaptatiope.

We propose a novel federated algorithm for learning dictionaries of empirical distributions for federated domain adaptation. The main idea of our approach is keeping server atoms public, whereas clientsâ€™ barycentric coordinates are private. Our strategy is based on two steps. First, one leans a neural net encoder through standard FedAVGÂ [9]. Second, we rethink the DaDiL strategyÂ [5] in a federated setting. Our end-to-end decentralized DA strategy improves adaptation performance on 5 visual DA benchmarks (tableÂ 2(e)). On top of that, we show that our strategy handles client parallelism better than previous works (figureÂ 2(c) and tableÂ 3), while being relatively lightweight in comparison with communication deep neural netsâ€™ parameters (figureÂ 3(a)). We further show that our method is robust with respect its hyper-parameters (figureÂ 3(b)), and that the alignment between the target domain and its reconstruction is better than with source domains (figureÂ 4).

FedaDiL. For our method, we performed grid-search on the batch size nbsubscriptğ‘›ğ‘n_{b}, number of atoms Kğ¾K and number of samples nğ‘›n. For the number of atoms, we search over Kâˆˆ{2,â‹¯,6}ğ¾2â‹¯6K\in\{2,\cdots,6\}. We further parametrize nbsubscriptğ‘›ğ‘n_{b} and nğ‘›n by the number of classes ncsubscriptğ‘›ğ‘n_{c} (c.f., Table 1 in our main paper). We display the best parameters in table 2 below, alongside the cost of communication for this set of parameters. Note that, as we explore in our experiments, the performance of our method is robust with respect the choice of hyper-parameters.

references: We compare FedDaDiL to other decentralized MSDA strategies over 5 visual DA benchmarks. We present an overview of our results in tableÂ 1. We use standard evaluation protocols in MSDA, namely, we perform adaptation with a ResNetÂ [37] backbone. The size of the backbone is selected to agree with previous researchÂ [6, 7, 8]. We run our experiments on a computer with a Ubuntu 22.04 OS, a 12th Gen Intel(R) CoreTM i9-12900H CPU with 64 GB of RAM, and with a NVIDIA RTX A100 GPU with 4GB of VRAM.

Decentralized Visual Domain Adaptation. In the following we refer to tableÂ 2(e), where we summarize our comparisons. First, FedAVG is a strong baseline when there is a limited amount of data. Indeed, on small benchmarks such as ImageCLEF and Office31, it performs better or equally than existing decentralized MSDA algorithms. This is not true on larger benchmarks, such as Adaptatiope.

Performance under Client Parallelism. We analyze the performance of FedDaDiL as we increase the degree of client parallelism, which is a function of the number of local iterations Eğ¸E. As we verified in the last section, for an increasing Eğ¸E FedDaDiL converges faster w.r.t. the rounds of communication rğ‘Ÿr. In tableÂ 3, we explore the performance of FedDaDiL-R and E in comparison with KD3AÂ [7] and Co-MDAÂ [8] w.r.t. Eğ¸E. Note that, in these previous works, the authors fixed E=1ğ¸1E=1 in their experiments. They further verified a degradation in performance for an increasing Eğ¸E.

As we verify empirically in tableÂ 3, there is indeed a degradation in KD3A and Co-MDA with an increasing Eğ¸E. Nonetheless, FedDaDiL-R and E keep approximately the same level of performance. As a result, on top of outperforming current SOTA, our method is more resilient to parallelism.

With respect figureÂ 3(a), while we cannot avoid communicating the whole networks during step 1 (FedAVG), the DaDiL step communicates much less parameters than the network used to encode its inputs. As a result, taking into account tableÂ 3 and figureÂ 3(a), the DaDiL step has better communication efficiency than previous decentralized MSDA methods.

We propose a novel federated algorithm for learning dictionaries of empirical distributions for federated domain adaptation. The main idea of our approach is keeping server atoms public, whereas clientsâ€™ barycentric coordinates are private. Our strategy is based on two steps. First, one leans a neural net encoder through standard FedAVGÂ [9]. Second, we rethink the DaDiL strategyÂ [5] in a federated setting. Our end-to-end decentralized DA strategy improves adaptation performance on 5 visual DA benchmarks (tableÂ 2(e)). On top of that, we show that our strategy handles client parallelism better than previous works (figureÂ 2(c) and tableÂ 3), while being relatively lightweight in comparison with communication deep neural netsâ€™ parameters (figureÂ 3(a)). We further show that our method is robust with respect its hyper-parameters (figureÂ 3(b)), and that the alignment between the target domain and its reconstruction is better than with source domains (figureÂ 4).

FedaDiL. For our method, we performed grid-search on the batch size nbsubscriptğ‘›ğ‘n_{b}, number of atoms Kğ¾K and number of samples nğ‘›n. First, one leans a neural net encoder through standard FedAVGÂ [9]. Second, we rethink the DaDiL strategyÂ [5] in a federated setting. Our end-to-end decentralized DA strategy improves adaptation performance on 5 visual DA benchmarks (tableÂ 2(e)). On top of that, we show that our strategy handles client parallelism better than previous works (figureÂ 2(c) and tableÂ 3), while being relatively lightweight in comparison with communication deep neural netsâ€™ parameters (figureÂ 3(a)). We further show that our method is robust with respect its hyper-parameters (figureÂ 3(b)), and that the alignment between the target domain and its reconstruction is better than with source domains (figureÂ 4).
